communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1905..

div.head: The Peace Terms. CHINA AND MANCHURIA. DELAY IN SIGNING TREATY.

div.p: An insignificant delay in the final drafting of the treaty prevented it from being signed yesterday. It will be signed this afternoon.

A synopsis of the treaty has been published. There are fifteen articles of which the gist is known. Each nation undertakes to employ its section of the Manchurian Railway solely for commercial and industrial purposes and to establish a junction at Quang Cheng, each will evacuate Manchria within 18 months, afterwards retaining 15 railway guards per kilometre, and each engages to place no obstacles in the way of China for the development of Manchuria. (Reuter)
The peace treaty has been signed. (Havas)

div.head: RUSSIA'S INTERNAL TROUBLES. COSSACKS CHARGE THE CROWD.

div.p: On the occasion of the departure of the reservists from Libau, the Cossacks charged the hostile crowd and fired upon the houses in tho vicinity. There are sixty killed and wonnd-ed and one hundred and fifty arrests have been made.
The troops charged a Jewish funeral at Kishineff. There are many killed and wounded.
Disorders continue in the interior. (Havas)

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY. ROSEN TO GO TO PARIS.

div.p: Baron Rosen, the new German Minister to Morocco, is about to come here to discuss with the French Government certain questions on which an undertaking is necessary before the conference can meet. (Reuter)

div.head: MACEDONIAN ACTIVITY. REDIF BATTALIONS CALLED OUT.

div.p: The Porte is calling out a number of Redif battalions to strengthen the troops in Macedonia. owing to a recrudescence of activity among the bands. (Reuter)

div.head: FIGHTING AT BAKU. REINFORCEMENTS PROM TIFLIS.

div.p: The fighting here continues, re-inforcements are being sent from Tifiia The disturbance appears to be racial and religions, but reports are very obscure. (Reuter)
The Tartars and Armenians have been fighting since Saturday. Until now there are 100 killed and wounded. The troops are engaged. (Reuter)

div.head: THE CHOLERA EPIDEMIC. PRECAUTIONS IN ENGLAND.

div.p: A case of cholera is reported here. (Reuter)

The Local Government Board has sent the Port Authorities a circular informing them of the precautions to be taken against ships arriving from the porta of the Baltic and North Seas infected with cholera. (Radar)
The hygienic commissions declare that there is nothing to be feared from the contagion of the cholera. (Havas)
The Shah is the object of much attention. It is rumoured that he hopes to obtain a loan of £250,000. (Reuter)
Colonel Frederick Wardrop has committed suicide on account of monetary troubles. (R.)

div.head: The Brindisi Mail
div.p: arrived at Port Said at six o'clock this morning and will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 9.80 p.m.

div.head: Suicide
div.p: M. Eustace Dahna, who was formerly cashier of the Alexandria branch of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, committed suicide yesterday.

div.head: Fall from a Scaffold
div.p: A native workman, named Mohamed Haikal, fell from a scaffold in the Rue d'Allemagne yesterday. His injuries were serious, and he was immediately sent to hospital

div.head: Shoubra Bridge
div.p: It is reported that the Ministry of Public Works has decided to enlarge the north end of the Shoubra bridge, so as to give the whole structure a uniform width of fourteen metres.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 33 vessels passed through the Canal during the first three days of September. 17 of these were British, 3 German, 9 French, 2 Austrian, 1 Italian, 1 Spanish. The amount received in dues was 718,168.07.

div.head: The Cotton-Worm
div.p: During the week end ing last Saturday there were ten feddans of land in the Behera moudirieh infected by the cotton-worm. These were cleared by 180 children, and the country is now pronounced free from the worm.

div.head: The Plaque
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin reports the admission to hospital of a Greek boy from a grocery in the Menshieh quarter, and a native woman, who has been isolated since the 31st. ult., owing to two members of her family having been found dead on that date.

div.head: Quarry Accident
div.p: A workman employed in one of the quarrier on the Mokattam Hills above the citadel was killed on Monday morning, while carrying a load. He appears to have slipped or become suddenly giddy, with the result that he fell over a cliff some eighty feet in height, and was killed on the spot.

div.head: Postal Van Accident
div.p: As a postal van was proceeding along Attarin Street, Alexandria, yesterday, one of the wheels was wrenched off by violent contact with the tramway line. The traffic was greatly impeded until the parcels had been transferred to another van, and the damaged one could be got out of the way.

div.head: Strange Story
div.p: A native of Damanhour was condemned to death to-day by the Assize Court for the murder of his wife, Questioned by the judge he stated that at the time of the murder be was dangerously ill, and fearing that his wife, for whom he had a passionate and jealous affection, would marry another after his death, he resolved to kill her himself.

div.head: "La Revue Internationale"
div.p: The September number of this review contains some excellent articles, among them M. Iesieur's interesting, if biassed, "1882, Souvenirs d'un Port-Saldien." M. Henry Davray contributes an article on English monthly and weekly periodicals of the day, and Mr. Pachundaki's contribution on "pre-historic man in Egypt" also deserves mention.

div.head: San Stefano Casino
div.p: A grand orchestral and vocal concert will be given on Saturday night on the occasion of the night fete at San Stefano Casino. The vocal part of the programme will include the execution of the whole of the third act of Puccini's La Bohema. After the concert there will be a display of fireworks and this will be followed by a small dance The whole programme provides for an exceedingly enjoyable evening, and the fete should be well attended.

div.head: A band of thieves
div.p: The El Rouei thieves recently arrested after one of their number bad shot a secret policeman, prove to be the authors of the burglary committed on the 10th ult. at the house of M. Chassesud in the Ismailieh quarter, when £150 worth of jewels were carried off. The accused are at present in the citadel prison, and the Italian Consular court will soon decide whether they are to be tried at Cairo or must appear before the Ancona Assize Court.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES AFFAIR. GENERAL MEETING DECIDED.
div.p: (By Telegraph.)
London, Tuesday, 3.15 p.m.

The managers of the Suereries et de la Raf-finerie d'Egypte continued their adjourned meeting at Paris to day in consultation with Sir Ernest Cassel and Maltre Carton de Wiart It was decided to convene a meeting of shareholders for the earliest possible date in view of the urgency of the matter. The secretary of the company started for Egypt to-day, and immediately on his arrival he will make preparations for a concordat according to Egyptian law, as such a course will be more profitable to the shareholders than winding up under the French law.

div.head: MOTOR ACCIDENT IN PARIS. COUNT ZOGHEB INJURED.
div.p: (By Telegraph.)
London, Tuesday, 11.15 am.

I have just learnt that while Count Antoine de Zogheb, Diplomatic Agent and Consul General for Denmark at Cairo, was driving his motor-car in the Bois de Boulogne, Paris, the car collided with a cab. The Count and five other occupants of the car were thrown out, and all received more or less severe injuries. We trust that Count Zogheb and his companions will speedily rearm from the effects of the accident

div.head: THE NEW NILE BRIDGES.
div.p: Through the kindness of Mr. Bakewell, the engineer in charge of the construction of the new bridges at Rodah Island we have learnt some interesting details concerning them. Mr. Bakewell has already been connected with several other important undertakings in this country, having first come out to Egypt in 1871, his last service being on the Assouan Reservoir, where he was engaged for five years. This gentleman is supervising the construction of the bridges on behalf of Sir William Arrol & Co., the contractors, and is assisted by Mr. Burnside, whilst Mr. Knowles acts on behalf of the Government. There an also several English foremen employed by the contractors.

The work is progressing very satisfactorily and it is fully expected that the new bridges will be completed by 1st June, 1907, the date fixed by the contract, as by the agreement entered into in June of last year between the Govern-ment and the above firm it was stipulated that they were to be handed over for traffic within 80 months, counting from the 1st December 1904, when the approaches and other preparatory works are to be finished by the Cairo Tanrim service. In the meanwhile we may remark, that the. land in the vicinity of the bridges at Old Cairo has gone up in price 50 per cent. within the past six months or so, and on the Island of Rodah it has doubled twice over. The original contract price was £191,813, but this figure was subsequently reduced by Sir William Arrol & Co. by £8,850, bringing down the price to £182,963. This reduction was agreed to in consideration of an alteration in the mode of payment by the Ministry of Public Works to the contractors, viz : in monthly instalments representing 90 per cent of the work done. But by a special clause introduced into the original agreement an additional sum of £3,000 may be added to the reduced cost of the bridges, for the lowering of the levels of the bottom of the Ghizeh and Rodah abutments.

The principal work in hand at present is the sinking of the cylinders, the preparation of the girders for the main bridge across the Nile proper ; and the sinking of the cylinders for the second bridge which is to connect Old Cairo with the island. Mr. Thomas, of Kafr el Zayat, is doing part of the cylinder sinking.

The larger bridge from Rodah to Ghiseh will be 535 metres long between the abutments and 90 metres wide. Two new roads on the island have been made by the Delta Light Railway Company, who brought the necessary earth and stones from a hill near by.

The two permanent bridges alluded to and the road across the island that connects them will form a straight drive of over a kilometre in length. There will be in time a double tramway line laid on the bridge, connecting the Old Cairo line with the Pyramids line, at a point nearly opposite the Zoological Gardena For this purpose, and in order to relieve the traffic on this new highway, a third bridge, 67 metres long, will be thrown across the branch of the Nile about a mile further away, and will be connected with the road across the island by another fine road 95 metres in width which is already completed. At the main bridge is to be at one of the many pictures que parts of the river it is intended to make the structure harmonise as for at possible with the beauty of the landscape. The drive across the whole length from Old Cairo to Ghizeh will become, no doubt, the most frequented in Cairo.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Syrian Prince left Malta yesterday with passengers and general cargo, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday.

The Kbedivial mail steamship Assouan will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Sunday next and Port Said at 4 p m. on Monday for Bey-rout, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandrette, Larnaca, limassol, Caiffa, and Jaffa,

div.head: GANG ROBBERY AT SALWA. A SHAWISH KILLED.
div.p: Edfou, Sunday.

On August 29. three robbers, all men of El Akaba village, surprised a fellah, who was driving his seven camels to Luxor for sale, near Salwa. They told him to give them all the money he carried and on his refusal, set upon him and beat him with nabouts, stole a camel, his clothes, and the sum of thirty three pounds, and made oft. One of the gang carried a gun which he discharged at the moment of the robbery but the shot fortunately missed its
The condition of the victim of this outrage gives rise to grave anxiety. He has been most cruelly beaten and his right leg and left arm are broken by the force of the blows.

The Omdeh of Salwa Bahari village, Dear which the crime was committed, informed the marks z, and the police moawen of the markaz with a doctor, after visiting the scene and seeing the wounded man, sent some Ababdeh Bedouin to follow the trail left by the gang. The Ababdehs returned with the news that they had come up with the robbers who fired on them and got safely away on their camels.

On August 31 the moawen, having collected a force of seven policemen, with some ghaffirs and Ababdeh, went into the desert, and after four hours march found the gang in a cave near the top of Jebel Esh-Shaaghebeh. A drop-ping fire was exchanged till 9 p.m. when shawish Ahmed Kenawi, who had climbed a height to reconnoitre, was shot dead. There upon the moawen and his men drew off the recovered camel and stolen clothes with them, and the robbers fled in the night He po-lice commandant of the moudirieh then went in search of the gang with four policemen, and after a day and a night found one of the robbers and the wife of another of their number together in the cave. Both confessed and gave the names of their accomplices, one of whom has since been captured while the police are on the track of the other.

div.head: FIRE AT BENHA.
div.p: ( From a Correspondent. )
Benha, Tuesday.

A destructive fire, involving the total loss of the general stores of Hassan-el-Harras Freres, the local agents of Messrs. Worms & Co., of Port Said, and which at times appeared in great danger of spreading further, started here some time after midnight, and burnt oat towards daybreak. The alum was apparently not given until the flames had obtained a firm hold over the highly inflammable materials contained in the stores, so that little could be done to save the adjacent premises. For-tunately no wind prevailed, otherwise the flames, leaping many yards above the neighbouring buildings, would have rapidly spread, while the means at hand for the work of extinction would have been hopelessly inefficient.

The hakimdar and mulahiz of police were quickly on the scene, and, assisted by the mudir's wakil and other residents, did all that was possible to prevent the extension of the fire, and to maintain order in the large crowd that rapidly assembled. The biasing ooal and wood contained in the ignited building,however rendered any attempt at extinction with a small hand engine futile, but the precautions taken to prevent the spread of the conflagration were fortunately attended with success.

The prevention and extinction of fires in the provinces is a subject which might well be given more attention than it has hitherto received. It should not be necessary, for in-stance, to telegraph to Cairo for assistance, while the efforts of volunteers might be better trained in order to prevent the indiscrimate and hopeless pouring of stream of water into the heart of a blazing furnace, while adjoining premises, in imminent danger from the contact of the flames, us waiting what may possibly prove salvation ; and those individuals who intercept the jets thrown by the hose, might also be kept within bounds.

div.head: OBITUARY. COLONEL WARDROP.
div.p: The late, Col. Frederick Meyer Wardrop, C.B., whose death is announced by a Renter's \ telegram of yesterday's date, was born in 1847, his father being the late Henry Wardrop of Blackfaulds, Lanarkshire. Entering the 3rd Dragoon Guardsin 1869 ,his military career was brilliant and his advancement rapid. In the | Egyptian campaign be acted as A D.C., to Sit Garnet (now Lord) Wolseley and was present at the actions of El Magfar, Tell el Mahuta, \ Ksssaeain and Tel el Kebir. He was mention- j ed in despatches, promoted to the brevet rack of Major, and was granted the Egyptian medal with clasp, 4th class of the Medjidieh and Khedive's star. Two years later in the expedi- tion of 1884-5 he played a distinguished part as D.A.A.G. and Q.M.G., was mentioned several , times in despatches, distinguished himself at Abu Klea and was promoted to the rank of Brevet Lieut-Colonel. From 1895 to 1902 Col . Wardrop was British Military attchae in Aus-tria-Hungary, Roumania and Servia, and from 1899 to 1902 in Montenegro as well. Col. War-drop was Colonel of the 18th Lancers and retired comparatively recently from the army. He married in 1895 Miss Mary Brooks Close, daughter of the late Daniel Paullin of Quincey Illinois, U.S.A. The deceased officer held numerous foreign decorations, among them that of Commander of the Frans Joseph order with star, and Commander of the Star of Rou-mania. He was an ardent rider and fisherman and enjoyed great personal popularity.

div.head: SOME PRESS COMMENTS. THE SULTAN'S ACCESSION.
div.p: From "Al Lewa."

"Every nation celebrates the succession days and birthdays of its Kings or Sultans and the whole world of Islam from Bast to West joined in celebrating the accession of Sultan Abdul Hamid. The recent fete day was more conspi-cuously and splendidly honored than all that bad gone before since our Sultan ascended the throne, for it was generally felt that the occasion demanded exceptional rejoicing in honor of Hie Majesty's escape from the dastardly attempt cm his life.

We need not go into particulars of the character of the Sultan. They are known to all. Every kingdom has within its borders fixe hostile to the common weal whose schemes mast be baffled by ministers and statesmen, but our exalted empire contains many foes and there is no one to combat their machinations but the Sultan himself. Vigilant, watchful, and active he has not burdened his people with too many debts, successful in war, he can be proud of hie victory over Greece which resulted in the recovery of an indemnity end may well be compared to the triumph of Japan over Russia, which like a tortoise has shrunk into its shell. His majesty has built warships, schools, and hospitals and has opened technical and military colleges, religions seminaries, and agricultural schools. He has constructed the Hedjaz Railway which has caused rage and apprehension among the English, and he is completing the railway to the Persian gulf, which will be of greet econom-ic end military importance."

div.head: "Levant Herald."
div.p: The "Levant Herald'' contains a long poem in French in honor of the occasion from which we quote two characteristic verses,
On pourralt lh-casus denombrer bien des falts, De noble tolerance., la Turqule, Oul, ches elle, Sout plus libres cont fols que dans tout Tunivers.

Lorsqu'nn sinistre eclate, en un lieu de l'Empire. Par an noble bonte, l'on voit nocher lon pleurs, Apures des maux le Ciel l'a m'a poor le reuxede. Et de la Providence., icl, representant. Bon heureuse influence. e late a chaque instant.

div.head: THE RECAPTURE OF SANA.
div.p: In a despatch dated August 25, Marshal Ahmed Fairi Pasha, then established at Souk-el-Hamis, made the following report on the progress of the campaign end the fighting in the passes

"I personally directed the operations undertaken against the rebels entrenched on the summits of the Jebel Shaib range. These heights, which era over 8,000 feet above sea-level commanded the position known as "Sinan Pasha," which is within five hours march of Sana. Our troops carried the enemy's trenches after two days fighting, and have now established the Army Head Quarters at Sinan Pasha, and sent detachments to other necessary points. Marshal Shakir Pasha has left with a sufficient force to occupy Bekti Redem, the principal rallying point of the insurgent

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The following is the programme of the vocal part of the concert to be given tomorrow evening:—

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit -within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: THE RAILWAY ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: To the Editor or Tire Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—I often read in your widely circulated paper reports not altogether creditable to the administration of the Egyptian State Railways. In your edition of October 8, 1908 you in published a forcible complaint from me regarding the overcrowding of carriages, in which I pointed out that the accommodation for ladies was insufficient. The railway authorities, however, do not seem to pay any attention to complaints, no matter from whom they originate. On Monday morning a family from Cairo, consisting of five adults and one child, ordered a seoond-class comportment at Sidi Gaber on the train leaving for Cairo at 7.9 a.m. Six full fares were charged and paid for, and the station master telephoned to Alexandria for a compartment to be reserved, and received an answer assuring him that it would be done. On the arrival of the train at Sidi Gaber no reserved compartment was to be found, and there was not even a vacant seat After a great deal of trouble the family were accommodated in an empty first-class carriage. A lady and little boy were leav-ing the same station by the 8-1 p m. train on that day. and asked the porter to put them in the ladies' compartment, but on the arrival of the train it was found to bo occupied mainly by native men and boys. None of the officials would send any of them intruders into another to the remonstrances of the lady or myself.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: E.T.C. v. Mr. S. J. DAWSON'S A. C. C. XI.

Played yesterday on the A.C.C. ground, resulting in a draw. The XL going in first declared after making 236 for seven wickets. Birley who played an excellent not ret innings of 81 was highest scorer. He hit tan fours in his innings and took rather more than an hour and a half to make his runs. Capt. Moore and Murphy also scored wall, both hitting with great freedom.

The E. T. C. began badly losing five wickets for 58, Stacey being the only one of the early batamen to give much trouble At this point Maclean, taking advantage of a bad let off at short slip, began to hit and found a most useful partner in Henley. Eighty six runs were added when Henley was bowled, after an innings which was most useful, if it made no gnat figure re the score sheet. Maclean continued to hit hard and often, his pulling bring remarkably severe and effective, and carried hie bat for a fine innings of 108, which included two sues, and fifteen boundary hits.
Full score and analysis :

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: The committee of the Alexandria Swimming Club asks us to announce that the 3rd annual aquatic sports will take plan on the 7th
Members times will be taken on the 23rd instant and all those who intend to are requested to be present.
The 60 yards juniors and 110 yds. seniors championships will take place on the 30th instant.
The venue will be announced later. He following is a list of events, which may be added to later

60 yds. juniors' handicap; 60 yds. seniors handicap ; 60 yds. veterans' race; Plunging championship ; Military Polo Match ; Polo match, Alexandria Swimming Club versus Rest of Alexandria; Military tug of war, tour a side ; Blindfold race ; Diving Competition ; Obstacle race ; Walking the pole; Military team race.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Webb, acting adviser to the Ministry of Public Works, retamed to Cairo from Assouan on Monday. He arrived at Alexandria tart night and after spending a short time here will return to Assouan on a visit of
Mr. Verschoyle. chief inspector of irrigations in Lower Egypt is at present paying a visit of inspection in the province, and will return to Cairo on Saturday.
Captain R.P. Crawley, A.S.C., has been granted leave of absence from the 21st inst. till November 20.
We are glad to hear that Mr. J.D. Wallieh, who left Egypt on July 22 on ordin-ary Wallieh returns to Egypt by the Austriaq Lloyd steamer leaving Trieste on Friday.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 5 Septembre 1905 à 5 h. p.m. sous la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents: MM. Ahmed Bey Byoub, L. Escoffier, Mansour Bey Youssef, Dr Schiess Bey, G. Zervadachi, membres, A. Willner, secrétaire p. i.

La Délégation prend connaissance d'une lettre de M. Karl Herold, exécuteur testamentaire de la succession E. Friedheim, communiquant un extrait du testament laissé par ce dernier et par lequel il lègue à la ville d'Alexandrie sa riche collection de tableaux à l'huile, aquaralles et eaux fortes, ainei qu'une somme de £400 destinée à servir de contribution à l'entretien de cette collection.
Ce don généreux sera soumis à la Commission Municipale pour son acceptation.

La Délégation prend note d'une lettre du 1er Septembre 1905 de l'Administration des Ports et Phares, communiquant copie de la lettre qu'elle a adressée au Ministère des Finances relativement aux réclamations faites par la Municipalité à l'occasion des nouveaux quais projetés sur la côte de Gabbary au Mex, pour le débarquement des bois.
Communication est donnée d'une note de M. Piot Bey, vétérinaire en chef Municipal, informant que la ladrerie bovine qui avait sévi ces temps derniers, est en pleine décroissance.

La Délégation arrête les termes du règlement tendant à la malléinisation obligatoire des solipèdes se trouvant dans le territoire d'Alexandrie et décide de le soumettre à l'approbation de la Commission Municipale dans sa prochaine séance.

Communication est donnée d'une propo sition de M. le Commandant de la Police tendant à l'acquisition d'une vingtaine de bouées de sauvetage pour porter secours aux ⚫ noyés ; ces bouées seraient mises à la disposition du Service des Garde-Côtes qui en serait chargé; la police de son côté, se ré- serve de prendre les mesures nécessaires pour la promulgation d'un arrêté obligeant les propriétaires des établissements de bains et hôtels, sis sur le bord de la mer, d'avoir en leur possession un nombre suffisant de ces bouées à mettre à la disposition du public.

La Délégation, vu l'intérêt que présente cette proposition au point de vue humanitaire et sans s'arrêter au principe touchant le point de savoir à qui doit incomber la dépense d'achat des bonées à remettre au service des Gardes Côtes, décide d'en faire l'acquisition et charge le Service Technique de lai remettre un devis à cet effet.

La Délégation autorise une dépense de LE 81 environ à prélever sur le crédit de la confection des nouvelles routes, pour délimiter par des bornes en maçonnerie, une partie des terrains municipaux de Chatby."
Ce travail est confié à Mohamed Abouchababah au prix de 75 P.T. le mètre cube de maçonnerie.

La Délégation adjage à M. Moscatelli, au prix de LE. 405, les travaux de dallage des rues Sidi Emad, Masgaid el Faham et le prolongement de la rue Attarine.d Communication est donnés d'une lettre Ministérielle approuvant le vote émis par la Commission Municipale relativement à l'orga nisation du Service des établissements insalubres et à la nomination des fonctionnaires et agents y désignés. Lotins

Sar la proposition du chef du service des plantations, la Délégation, à l'occasion de l'asphaltage des trottoirs de la rue d'Allemagne, décide de remplacer les arbres de cette avenue, plantés irrégulièrement ou abimés, par des lebbetts, de manière à satisfaire aux exigences de l'esthétique et de l'uniformité.
La Délégation prend connaissance de l'état des recettes municipales du 1er janvier au 31 août 1905 s'élevant sur le budget ordinaire à L.E. 166,363 et pour le budget extraordinaire à LE 49,311.
Les dépenses pour la même période se mon tent à LE. 116,804 sur le budget ordinaire et A LE 16,852 sur le budget extraordinaire. La séance est levée à 6 h. p.m.
Une petition a M. Dunlop Il existe à Alexandrie et au Caire deux écoles fondées par fea Ratib Pacha et placées par lai sous la surveillance da Ministère de PInstruction Publique.
Un wakf a été constitué en faveur de ces deux établissements qui doivent être complète ment gratuits et exclusivament destinés aux enfants appartenant à la classe pauvre.

Or depuis quelque temps la direction de l'école d'Alexandrie ne reçoit guère que des enfants de familles riches ou aisées qui pourraient facilement payer une rétribution scolaire dans les écoles gouvernementales ou privées. Certains des élèves actuels appartiennent à la noblesse indigène, à la catégorie des notables et des commerçants, et, pour que la note gaie ne manque pas, à des familles de conseillers municipaux.

Voilà qui peut convenir à la rage économique de ces messieurs, mais qui s'éloigne fort de l'intention du généreux donateur. Une pétition couverte de signatures venant d'être adressée & M. Dunlop pour lui rappeler la destination originaire de ces écoles et le prier de mettre bon ordre à ces abus, nous nous faisons un devoir d'appuyer la jaste demande des inté- ressés, c'est-à-dire des pauvres indignement spoliés de leurs droits.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The firm of Messrs. Ougini Praga has the

honor to inform the public that in consequence of a common agreement it has renounced, in favor of the Représentance Générale de la Neuchatel Asphalte Co. Ltd. of London, the work of compressed asphalt, both in Egypt and Upper Italy. 26868-1

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: THEATRE ALHAMBRA

Ce soir on donne à l'Alhambra une des plus brillantes comédies du répertoire "La Trovata del Brasiliano" pièce qui a été représentée avec un immense succès sur tous les théâtres lu monde. Les premiers rôles sont tenus par MM. Della Guardia, V. Zacchi, F. Valenti, R. Malvios et Mmes L. Giordani, D. Dolfini, G. Bonfiglioli, G. Gasparini.
Oa donnera prochainement la tragédie de Cesareo "Francesca da Rimini" et le drame de Sardou "La Sorcière", deux pièces également célèbres.
Lundi, pour la soirée en l'honneur de M. F. Valenti, on représentera la comédie de Wolf "Il Segreto di Palcinella."

Pour satisfaire aux nombreuses demandes qui lui ont été adressées, la direction met à la disposition du public une dernière émission de carnets de 30 billets au prix de 300 P.T. et transmissibles. Parmi ces trente représentations figurent les meilleurs chefs-d'œeavra da théâtre moderne, ainsi que les nouveautés les plus sensationnelles, telles que: La Sorcière, de Sardoa; La Gioconds, de G. d'Annunzio; l'Altro, de W. Lindau; La Casa di Bambola, da E. Ibsen; A Sant'Elena, de M. Severine; La Crisi, de M. Praga; Il Segreto di Palcinella, de P. Wolf; Le Détour, de B. Barnstein; La Trovata del Brasiliano, de Honcey et Armont; Lùlù, de C. Bertolazzi; Il Viaggio di Nozza, de G. A. Traversi; Il Diavolo et l'Acqua Santa, de C. Bertolazzi.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourd'hui à midi et demis)
Oa a fait quo'qaes milliers d'Estates et une certaine quantité de Sacreries et d'Agricole ; msis, en général, la corbeille des valeurs demeure calme et insotive.

Le prix des Estates se maintient à 1 1/4. Ba Sacreries on débate à 42, atteint 45 et olotare à 44. A Paris la cote marqua 47. deg Las administrateurs de la Société des Saoreries at Raffinerie d'Egypte ont poursuivi hier à Paris leurs pourparlers avec Sir Braest Cassol et Maltre Carton de Wiart. Il a été décidé de convoquer une assemblée des action- naires aussi tôt que possible, va l'urgence. Le secrétaire général de la société est parti hier même pour l'Egypte et dès son arrivée au Caire il prendra les mesures voulues pour élaborer un concordat d'après la loi égyptienne, solation qui est bien plus profitable aux actionnaires que d'entendre déclarer la Société en faillite selon la loi française. den pad of

Un recul à lien pour les grosses valeurs: la Nationale fléchit de 27 3/4 à 27 5/8 l'Ancienne et de 27 5/8 à 27 1/2 la nouvelle, l'Agricole de 14 13/32 à 14 11/32, la Daira de 27 18/16 à 27 3/4, et les Eaux du Caire de 1165 à 1155. Les Tramways d'Alexandrie fléchissent également de 160 à 159 les Privilégiées et de 330 à 325 les Dividendes, la Ramlah Railway de 7 1/8 à 71/16, et l'Investment de 1 9/32 à 1 1/4. adgilar insa Cependant la Salt & Soda monte de 34/6 à 35/3, l'Alexandria Water de 15 à 15 1/16 et la Banque d'Athènes de 137 1/2 à 128.426d

div.p: CONTRATS
Fluctuations de 9h.30 à 1h. p.m.
Dans la matinée; prix plus haut pour nov tal. 14 12/32 à —/— ; plus bas pour nov. 14 19/32 à — /—.
Dans la matinée ; prix plus haut pour nov-dec-jan.. P.T. 58 25/40 à —/—: plus bas pour nov.-dec-jan. 58 10/40 à —/—.
Remarques
(De midi à 1h. p.m.)
Coton. -Après le soutien du matin, il y a eu un peu d'inaction, et comme Liverpool n'a offert aucun encouragement à l'ouverture, la clôture chez nous a fini par avoir lieu en léger recul.
Graines de coton.-La clôture a été de meilleare ton qu'à l'ouverture, mais il y a eu manque d'activité dans toute la matinée. Fèves.-Affaires nullos,
Bourse Khédiviale, le 5 septembre 1905.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
